Problem:
Consider a physical system represented by heat equation \\( u_t = \\kappa \\Delta u \\) where \\( \\kappa \\) is the thermal diffusivity. An external heat source influences the system described by \\( h(x, t) \\) being added to certain regions at specific times.

If a specific heat source profile \\( h(x, t) \\) is introduced at time \\( t_1 \\) and then removed at \\( t_2 \\), will the temperature distribution at \\( t = T \\) (where \\( T > t_2 \\)) be independent of the heat source profile?
Explanation: The introduction and subsequent removal of a heat source alters the temperature distribution transiently, and these changes persist even after the source is removed. The final temperature distribution at time \\( T \\) retains memory of this intervention, thus not being solely dictated by the initial conditions or natural diffusion.
